name: Overview
main:
In 2014, Islamic State (IS) took over significant portions of Iraqi territory, triggering mass displacement and severe humanitarian needs. After a military stalemate throughout much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from IS were stepped up in 2016 and are ongoing in 2017, aggravating displacement and humanitarian needs, such as health and WASH, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors.? Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern.

Iraq now hosts three million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world.? Over two million IDPs have returned to their areas of origin, since October 2016.?IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).?

INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.8/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.6/10 and 6.9/10 rates.?
latest_developments_past:
02/11: Since Iraqi forces and allied militias moved into disputed areas previously held by the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) an estimated 183,000 have been displaced from Ninewa, Kirkuk, Erbil and Diyala. ??

31/10: The number of IDP returnees has increased from 1.4 million in January to over 2.6 million as of 31 October. Anbar governorate has seen the highest rate of returns, followed by Ninewa and Salah al Din. Significant protection risks, as well as a lack of essential services and livelihood opportunities in newly liberated territories means that conditions are not yet suitable for returns.?
latest_developments_upcoming: National elections are scheduled to be held in May 2018.
